reviewText: This is the definitive Doc Martin collection comprising the five series plus the movies which have been released to date. Doc Martin has aired between 2004 and 2011 and there have been a total of 37 episodes broadcast plus the Christmas Special in 2006 and the two movie length episodes which preceded the first series.Doctor Martin Ellingham or Doc Martin was formerly a highly successful surgeon in a London hospital, who was forced to leave this job due to a fear of blood. He takes the job of GP in the sleepy Cornish village of Portwenn and is soon finding it difficult to relate to the locals due to what he considers his businesslike approach, but which is interpreted by those on the receiving end as standoffishness and a total lack of empathy and bedside manner. This extends to his personal life and his difficult relationship with the long suffering Louisa since he has very little in the way of people skills and a total inability to express emotion.Portwenn is one of those places where nothing very significant seems to happen for a lot of the time, but which is inhabited by a gentle range of eccentric locals whom the stories are built around and the whole mix makes for very good and often quite amusing entertainment. Martin Clunes excels as Doc Martin and plays the part with a largely expressionless face except for the odd twinge of exasperation or irritation which occasionally crosses his brow. He has made this part his own and you really cannot imagine anyone else as Doc Martin. There is a very able supporting cast, but the principal characters have varied from series to series.Although this contains the 5 series of Doc Martin to date and the two prequels, purchasers should be aware that a sixth series is now confirmed for 2013. However, this will very likely be the final series. I would have thought that Doc Martin was one of those scenarios where it was possible to keep producing fresh scripts so personally I am certainly hoping for more!
summary: Definitive Doc Martin Box Set.........So Far!

reviewText: If you want humor, if you want "laugh out loud" humor "Doc Martin" is the ticket. Having followed the series on PBS, I had to have all five seasons, and I know I will be watching it over and over, as I do "Downton Abbey" and other British drama.Doc Martin, a man who's far from being "user friendly" is the story of a man whose emotional fabric was somehow stunted somewhere along his upbringing, but one discovers his softer side slowly.  Discovering "Doc Martin" is like pealing an onion, you have to do it layer by layer, as you deal with the causticity caused by the process.  Incapable of expressing his softer side, he blusters through on a daily basis in a way that is hysterically funny though simultaneously pitiable.  The cast of characters is absolutely the best combination for fun and laughter.

reviewText: I've become addicted.  What an incredibly interesting character Doc Martin is.  He's a highly trained surgeon, but because he has developed a phobia to blood, he returns to his little port town in Cornwall, England from hospital in London to become a G.P.  The characters in the town play off this doctor who shows no bedside manner (or any other manners) whatsoever.  However, he's an incredibly caring doctor and is totally dedicated to his patients, especially in emergencies.  Unique and funny.  F. Parker

reviewText: This winning hit combines a country doctor, who faints at the sight of blood, with quirky villagers, and fantastic English seaside visual charm. Now the entire 38 episode series is packaged together, along with 2 TV movies that spawned the series. It's a must-see-all opportunity in the full-deal package. A set to own, for continuing viewing privilege; time after time. A comedy classic British production.SUBTITLES- yes!TV Season 1: Martin Clunes plays the London surgeon moving into sleepy Portwenn. Viewers are introduced to characters so odd they become household names. 6 episodes of hysterical hilarity.2: Nine new episodes fail to ease the surly self-centered doctor. Romance (Caroline Catz) lingers on Cornish fishing village streets.3: Doc's aunt (Stephanie Cole) is one of the less eccentric locals through the season's 7 episodes. Bert Large (Ian McNeice) plumber turned chef is wildly goofy as is Doc's receptionist.4: The previous season ended in a surprise and they continue in 8 episodes with romance and blood sparking rumors, even a ghost.5: Doc Martin (Martin Clunes) had packed prepared for a new position out of Portwenn. But girlfriend Louisa, a nameless son, & Aunt did not love his planned exit. That was then. Now we have 8 new episodes, and enjoy you will.THE MOVIES: Doc Martin- 87 min.Doc discovers 3 doctor friends have bedded his wife. A trip to seclusion ends in Port Isaac mud and a lobster boat gig.Doc Martin and the Legend of the Cloutie- 75 min. Doc stoops to cloutie-ing to get an out-of-the-way home he must fight for.You will never regret buying this HUGE  38 episode plus 2 feature length movie SET. Laugh from minute one till the end.Not enough of Martin Clunes yet?--Try "Dirty Tricks" and "Reggie Perrin."
summary: Fully packed with jovial Rx from Doc Martin
Title: N/A

reviewText: We (wife and I), could not stop watching this series. We had seen most of these out of order on PBS. We are so glad we bought the set and the 6th season as well. Endlessly funny IF you appreciate not suffering fools gladly. Doc Martin says what many of us would love to say, but have more social graces than to utter. He certainly is not a great role model, but his fits of pique are brilliant.I get the feeling people are going to like or hat Doc Martin. I don't see much room for middle ground. We have shown this set to friends and have been surprised at the reception (highly positive) the it got, mainly because these people might tend to be a bit overly socially conscious if not outright politically correct. They still roared. That, in and of itself, says something.Good audio mix, clear dialog. No laugh track, thank God! Another Clunes vehicle is Reggie Perrin. Very funny, Clunes at his sarcastic peak, but overwhelmed by a senseless laugh track (or if live, the poorest audio mix I've ever heard). Still well worth viewing for the Martin Clunes fans.
summary: Exquisitely Funny - If One Appreciates Social Dysfunction and Sarcasm

reviewText: After watching a half dozen episodes of Doc Martin on PBS, I ordered this collection and was won over by the story and characters.  In many ways this is an English Ballykissangel. The characters and stories are very different but they've created another quirky village as a pretext for a comedy of culture clash.  While BallyK was more of a comedic soap with the ensemble playing their expected roles, Doc Martin is a personality driven comedy about an uncompromising high achiever completely out of his element.  So far they've avoided the downward spiral Ballykissangel took after season 3, though a cast change in Series 5 has had a few detractors and I thought it the weakest of the 5 sets.Martin Clunes is in rare form as the cantankerous Dr. Martin Ellingham who is seemingly tormented on a daily basis by the odd assortment of village patients inhabiting picturesque Portwenn. Forced to give up his practice as a London surgeon due to a comedically ironic bout of haemophobia he's selected to replace the former GP in this Cornish fishing village.  A less suitable candidate could hardly be imagined. Martin's brusque manner and insulting intolerance to his patients' country ways set the stage as the episodes follow one hilarious plot after another.  Along the way he enters into an improbable romance  with the local school teacher (surely the most forgiving woman in all of Cornwall) and becomes an object of the local chemist's sexual obsession.  It's hard to explain just why this is so terribly funny when the core joke is that Martin is such a disagreeable person, but it is. As the series plays out you start to empathize with him as he slowly becomes an essential part of the community even while planning a return to his former life.The origin of the Doc Martin character dates back to the 2000 theatrical release "Saving Grace", but evolved significantly prior to this iteration.  In the film and TV movies, Clunes plays Dr. Martin Bamford whose demeanor is significantly different, as is his medical specialty, his personal life, and the circumstances that brought him to Port Isaac (renamed Portwenn in the series).  Apparently this singular role struck such a chord with Clunes that he hung on to it and has brought it to near perfection in this hilarious and oddly touching series.I rated this with 4 stars rather than 5  for a couple of reasons.  First, the package includes the two UK TV movies that are mildly entertaining but nowhere near the level of the series.  Secondly, I was a bit disappointed with Series 5.  I'm glad they made it, but I didn't feel it rose to the same level as the previous four.  So 5 stars for Series 1 thru 4 and a star off for a the more mundane movies and Series 5.  Included with the 38 episodes and two feature length TV movies is more than an hour of behind the scenes background video, so the current street price works out to a little more than $1 per hour of entertainment, a bargain by just about any standard.UPDATE;  GOOD NEWS FOR DOC MARTIN FANS:  THE FIRST EPISODE  OF SERIES 6 AIRED SEP 1 ON ITV.  HOPEFULLY A REGION 1 CODING WILL BE AVAILABLE IN A FEW MONTHS.

reviewText: Who wouldn't want to live in Port Wenn? This TV show makes practically everyone want to live in this eye-candy village, where it's always sunny and bright. The show was actually filmed on location in the village of Port Isaac, Cornwall, England  ---- the location of my next summer vacation. Well, back to the show, you can imagine the fun of a TV show in which the main character is a doctor who is afraid of blood, but in reality, the series is endearing and one begins to really like Doc Martin and all of the other idiosyncratic characters in this small village. After buying and watching some TV series, I can sell them or pass them on, but this one is a keeper -- you can watch it again and again, and there is always sometime fun and new to discover ... and it's just visually beautiful to watch!

reviewText: From the first episode in the first series, to the last in the 5th I was absolutely hooked!  Somehow you fall in love with this poor British Dr. who has no social skills or bedside manner.  Maybe it's because you can relate to the difficulties he has with the quirky people in this town with some very strange medical conditions or maybe it's because it's hysterically funny, awkward, serious, touching and fun all rolled together.  I'm in my 50's and absolutely every friend my age I've recommended this show to absolutely LOVES it and thanks me for telling them about it.  You will not be sorry you purchased this.  I'm not, and I've probably watched every episode at least 4 times now.  It's a breath of fresh air after so many of these reality shows that are on TV these days!
summary: The Doc I LOVE to hate!  Or is it love?!

reviewText: Doc Martin is a pleasure to watch. My wife and I purchased this series and just put in our order for the sixth season. It is such a pleasure to watch something serious, with humor put in throughout the DVD/movie. The scenery is absolutely fantastic. We are starting to watch seasons 1-5 over. And it is amazing how many small things you miss from first viewing. Having dealt with the public in retail sales for 10 yrs, I certainly can relate to Doc Martin's frustration dealing with people. Also, I finally came to the conclusion that he is compensated from the community, taxes or something. And that the medical care is paid for by socialized medicine as you never hear about a charge for services. Also I am old enough to remember a doctor coming to my house when I was really sick. House calls at least in the USA are non-existant. I hope the writers never run out of material for their stories as this is a pleasure to watch.
summary: Best TV to Come Along in Ages
Title: N/A

reviewText: Doc Martin's behavior is outrageous and offensive, but so much so that he is absolutely hilarious. His relationship skills would test a saint.  It is interesting to see the British system of socialized medicine and compare it to ours.  Apparently, general practitioners are paid by the government and assigned to areas where health care is needed. They make assessments and then refer patients to specialists. I have never seen such an accident-prone village.

reviewText: Doc Martin, the character, is different.  As the focus of this comedic drama, he pulls together all the characters through his practice, the surgery.  His love interest is a question from beginning to end; however, all ends happily; I think.  In a world where reality seems to be the key, this story develops characters that we each can identify with and expect in our daily lives.  I love the little village of Portwen and could see myself living there.  The medical system is very different there and would take some getting use to though.  :-)  The only thing that comes close to this series of dramas in the States is Hallmark movies.

reviewText: Watching an hour of "Doc Martin" always makes me feel good. Imagine the thrill of having all 6 seasons lined up! The Doc is hard to like, as was the famous Dr. Gregory House, but in contrast, Doc Martin has a very broad streak of humaneness that underlies and guides all he does. The setting is beautiful, the stories are funny, serious, and heart-warming at the same time, and the cast of supporting characters really do feel like friends & family after only a few episodes. This is a great addition to my "personal rerun" list.
summary: Port Wenn seems like my extended family!

reviewText: I liked the Doc Martin series on PBS but they had a nasty habit of only showing it here around 3, 4, or 5 AM and I missed most of them.  So, I broke down and bought them !!!  The music is a little annoying but British TV can be that way ... so, get over it.  Besides, on DVD, you can rapid through all that and avoid it.  So, I have enjoyed the series ... all of it ... in order of presentation.  I would recommend "Doc Martin Special Collection: Series 1-5" to anyone that enjoys British humor TV series's.
summary: Doc Martin ... all seasons on DVD

reviewText: love this series and can't wait for no. 6.  The movie that inspired the series is not as good as the series.  No. 1 thru 4 were the best of the 5.  I didn't like some of the changes made in the part 5 but still very good.  Some of the medical miracles performed out in a field are a little farfetched but otherwise very entertaining and addictive.
summary: Very enjoyable and well worth the money....highly recommended.

reviewText: We watched this program on PBS but unfortunately missed part of it.  Now we are enjoying the whole thing.  It has a great story line, no filthy dialog, believable characters and we'll enjoy it again and again.
summary: THIS IS A PROGRAM FOR PEOPLE WHO WANT TO THINK!!!!!

reviewText: This is the best price that you will find anywhere and if you like Doc Martin, you will be very happy with this set.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This series is fun, entertaining, enlightening and one of those things that could be watched time after time without fear of growing old.  Doc Martin and the entire cast are an endearing bunch who quickly become familiar, almost to the point that they become family.  Their odd quirks are fun and turn what could have become a boring soap opera into a rollercoaster ride with an exciting twist at every turn.
